Should religions be defined and judged by their original intention or by their actual practice?
 
 So often in history and today, various groups claim that their extremist views are consistent with a particular religion when they are really utter distortions - militant extremist Islam and certain far right Christian groups come to mind. Part of the problem lies in the vagueness of many original religious texts which allow for diverse interpretations. However, my guess is that the main problem lies with people forming their views first based on tribal or group traditions or emotional reactions to current history, and then trying to fit their particular religion into their views - often only paying attention to those parts of the religious texts that suit their purposes.
 
 So, what are your views on this issue? Are religions defined by their original intent (to the degree that it can be determined) or by the actual practice? Also, is it the responsibility of the main-stream believers to try to reign in those that take extremist views in the name of their religion?

 Very few religions have clear-cut origins. Taking the long view, Christianity is just an off-shoot of Judaism; and Judaism itself seems to have evolved from a mish-mash of Early Near Eastern religions, with the Yahweh/El figure emerging as a composite of Baal-like predecessors. This being the case, 'straying from their origins' is hardly an issue: their 'origins' lay in a departure from pre-existing socio-economic conditions; when those conditions change again, further change is hardly unexpected.

 Christianity was different enough from Judaism, the religion it sprang from, that it became a new religion. Similarly, Buddhism started off as an offshoot of Hinduism. At some point, beliefs change enough from their origins that one can call those new beliefs a new religion. I admit that there is often no clear dividing line and such separations are often mired in politics as well. For example, a number of early Christian church leaders wanted to keep Christianity within the realm of Judaism - including St. Peter, if I am not mistaken. 
 
 My main point is that religions are not and cannot be completely flexible. Also, a lot of these extremist offshoots are not rejecting the main text to show flexibility in the religion they claim to follow. They mainly still claim to honor those main text but they seem to only pay attention to them selectively while simply ignoring those parts that don't suit their purposes.
